title: Improper access control for users with expired password, giving the user full access through API and Git

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
### Summary

Users with an "expired password" can still access the full API with tokens. This includes the REST API, GraphQL API and Git HTTP access. The same issue was mitigated in [13.12.2](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/2021/06/01/security-release-gitlab-13-12-2-released/#insufficient-expired-password-validation) as "Insufficient Expired Password Validation". That patch blocked users with expired passwords from accessing the REST API. My report [1192460](https://hackerone.com/reports/1192460) led to a patch [14.0.2](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/2021/07/01/security-release-gitlab-14-0-2-released/#a-deactivated-user-can-access-data-through-graphql) that also blocked access through GraphQL.

It seems that these patches caused some problem for users accessing GitLab instances using LDAP. And a [merge request](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/63466) trying to address this problem got merged in one of the latests releases. Unfortenetly this new "fix for LDAP" also seems to have opened up access for regular user accounts with expired passwords again.

__Images showing access through REST, GraphQL and Git with a account with expired password:__

{F1394654}

{F1394656}

{F1394657}

### Steps to reproduce
(tested on 14.1.0 self-hosted)

1. Create a user user01, and log in
2. Create a new project at https://gitlab.domain.com/projects/new#blank_project make sure to put it as `private`. Take a note of the ID of the project
3. Go to https://gitlab.domain.com/-/profile/personal_access_tokens and create a personal access token
4. Log in as an administrator
5. Go to the admin page for editing the user https://gitlab.domain.com/admin/users/user01/edit and change the users password. This triggers `password expired at` to be set to the current time. Effectively putting the user01 in the state of "expired password""
6. Trying to log in as user01 with old password will now fail, using the new password will trigger "enter a new password" page. __Do not enter a new password here as this will put the user in a unexpired state again__

{F1394655}

7. Now instead try to use the user01 token from step 2 in a REST request such as
```
curl --request GET \
  --url https://gitlab.domain.com/api/v4/projects/:ID \
  --header 'Authorization: Bearer <TOKEN>' \
```
This should show the `private` project that should not be accessible.

### Impact

A user that should not have access to the instance as the password has expired can still access the API and Git with tokens.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Requests to the API and Git is not blocked for users with expired password

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Requests to the API and Git by users with expired password should be blocked and presented with a message like `403 Forbidden - Your password expired. Please access GitLab from a web browser to update your password.` as before.

## Impact

Users with expired passwords can still access the full API and Git using tokens

activities.message:
I have made some additional research into the issue that I thought I can share with you.

First of to fend of any doubts from the H1 triage team as whether the behavior is a vulnerability or expected behavior. Last time I reported an issue related to "expired password" I got it confirmed that this user state should also block access with tokens. As I will describe below, the current bug allows a user with an expired password to:

1. pull and push to git repos using the expired password
2. access the APIs with `personal access tokens` as well as `oauth2 tokens`(generated with the expired password)
3. generate new OAuth connections without updating the password

Source code that confirms that an expired password should block such actions can be found in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/policies/global_policy.rb
```
  rule { password_expired }.policy do
    prevent :access_api
    prevent :access_git
    prevent :use_slash_commands
  end
```
And in the latest MR that generated the new bug there is a test case that should test for this but that apparently fails to catch (more on that later). https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/spec/models/user_spec.rb
```
    subject { user.password_expired_if_applicable? }
    context 'when user is not ldap user' do
  
   ...

      context 'when password_expires_at is in the past' do
        let(:password_expires_at) { 1.minute.ago }

        it 'returns true' do
          is_expected.to be_truthy
        end
      end
```
This test aims to prove that a non LDAP user with expired password, the `password_expired_if_applicable?` should return true.

This method on the `User` model, `password_expired_if_applicable?`, seams to be the root cause to the current problems. The method contains a check
```
return false unless password_expired? && password_automatically_set??
```
Which was added in this [commit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/commit/366b1d7457e12f1454c1001f93d7d43330ddd59d).

The problem is that this method would always yield false for normal users, as `password_automatically_set?` is false as default. It might be that I miss understand the flow here. But as far as I could see the `password_automatically_set?` is more relevant for LDAP users. As seen in the image below I can force a user's password to expire by setting the expiration date in the past. This makes the old `password_expired?` to show `true` while the `password_expired_if_applicable?` is still showing false.

{F1396217}

The reason for the test mentioned above to pass could be related to the user being created during testing getting a `password_automatically_set`. I have not been able to confirm this though.

Anyhow, this leads to `password_expired_if_applicable?` yielding false for normal users at any time, even when the password have expired. Looking through the code base this would allow access to Git (by token and by the expired password), usage of tokens (OAuth and personal) accessing the API, usage of tokens and password to access Git LFS storage.

An interesting example can be viewed in my video recording bellow. When a user with expired password log in, GitLab will prompt for updating the password. But even so, the user can still access OAuth authentication pages for applications and generate new tokens.

{F1396231}
Hi @joaxcar - I'm discussing this submission internally with the GitLab team. You will be updated as soon as there is additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!

Thank you @turtle_shell for looking into this,

I realized that the vulnerability was added in a later MR ([65575](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65575)). This MR explicitly adds the exception to `password_automatically_set?` in `password_expired_if_applicable?`. All this starts to look like a hack to bypass the security fix in 13.12.2, and one starts to wonder "who are the users that are applicable for API block when password has expired?" as it is not  LDAP users, not other accounts that fail, not normal users, not bots and so forth. I think that this undermines the business logic that underlies the 13.12.2 fix, __a user with expired password should not be able to access the API or other resources__.

One example is of course the one given in my original posting. A user that gets the password reset by an Admin. Others are the GitLab instance operators discussing a suggested feature enabling admins to set instance wide expiration policies. Discussed here [issue 16555](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/16555). This thread also contains a work around that administrators can use at the moment, involving setting expiration dates through the GitLab console.

All this makes the current "fixes" look like workarounds that will come back and generate greater problems in the near future. A more correct fix would probably be to force LDAP users to have an expiration date set to Nil.

Hello @joaxcar,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/337954.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Costel
GitLab Security Team

ETA for fix:

Hi @joaxcar,

The issue you reported is currently scheduled to be fixed by 2021-10-31.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

Hi @joaxcar,

Thank you again for the report! Your finding has been patched in GitLab version 14.3.1 and we are awarding a bounty. Congratulations!

Please let us know if you find that our patch does not mitigate your finding. Your report will be published in 30 days in GitLab's issue tracker. If you'd like to publicly disclose this report or details of it in a blog post or elsewhere, please allow 30 days to pass before doing so to give time to our customers to upgrade to a patched version.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
Costel
GitLab Security Team

Hi @gitlab_cmaxim thank you for the fix and for the bounty!

I saw that the issue was attributed to ngalog in the patch blog post. Could this be changed to mention my handle instead?

Best regards
Johan

Hey @joaxcar, 

My apologies for the error. Will correct that as soon as possible. 

Thanks for checking,
Costel

Hi @gitlab_cmaxim 
Could we disclose this report?

Best regards Johan

> Could we disclose this report?

Sure! 

Looking forward for your next report.
Costel
